titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Eleanor Clark Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:58

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Eleanor Clark Papers consists of writings, correspondence, and other materials documenting the life and work of the writer Eleanor Clark.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some materials in Italian.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Eleanor Clark Papers was acquired through purchase and gifts. The bulk of the collection was acquired through purchase from Eleanor Clark in 1988. Additional materials were added to the collection through gifts from Eleanor Clark, in 1994 and 1996, and from Rosanna Warren, in 2005 and 2007.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Restricted Fragile papers in boxes 52-53 may be consulted only with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies or photographic prints for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Eleanor Clark Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Eleanor Clark Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Eleanor Clark Papers contains material formerly classed as Uncat ZA MS 68, Uncat ZA MS 410, Uncat ZA MS 479, Uncat MSS 845, and Uncat ZA File 711.

bioghist.head: Eleanor Clark (1913-1996)
bioghist.p: Eleanor Clark was the author of critically acclaimed novels and non-fictional works from the mid 1940s to mid 1980s, as well as short fiction, essays, poems, and plays. Novels included Bitter Box (1946), Baldur's Gate (1970), Gloria Mundi (1979), and Camping Out (1986). Non-fictional works included the travel narratives Rome and a Villa (1952) and Oysters of Locmariaquer (1965), which won the National Book Award, and the memoir Eyes, Etc. (1977).

Eleanor Clark was born July 6, 1913, in Los Angeles, California, raised in Roxbury, Connecticut, and educated at Vassar. She worked as a freelance writer, editor, and translator in the mid 1930s and as an editor for W.W. Norton & Company in New York from 1936 to 1939. Clark married Robert Penn Warren on December 7, 1952.
Summary information on Eleanor Clark is available in the standard print and online biographical resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Eleanor Clark Papers consists of writings, correspondence, and personal papers documenting the life and work of the writer Eleanor Clark. Writings include work spanning over fifty years, from short stories and poems written and published while Clark was a undergraduate at Vassar in the early 1930s to the late fiction and non-fiction of the 1980s. The writings feature notes, drafts, proofs, and printed materials relating to Clark's published works of fiction and non-fiction, from drafts of what would become Baldur's Gate , dating from the mid 1930s, to drafts of her last novel, Camping Out (1986). In addition, there are drafts and printed versions of numerous published and unpublished shorter works, including short stories, essays, poems, plays, speeches, readings, and book reviews.

Correspondence in the collection consists chiefly of incoming letters from family, friends, writers, editors and publishers, and educational and cultural institutions. Larger correspondence files may be found for Clark's husband, Robert Penn Warren, her mother, her two children, Gabriel and Rosanna Warren, and Louis MacNeice, Katherine Anne Porter, and Muriel Rukeyser, among others. Other noteworthy correspondents include authors W.H. Auden, Saul Bellow, Hermann Broch, Albert Camus, John Cheever, Robert Fitzgerald, Elsa Morante, Eudora Welty, Glenway Wescott, and Thornton Wilder. There are also files of correspondence, including fan mail and letters from publishers, relating to published works.
Other materials include college papers, journals, and notebooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into three series: I. Writings, 1915-1993. II. Correspondence, 1876-1988. III. Personal Papers, 1881-1988.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Writings is organized into two subseries: Writings of Eleanor Clark and Writings of Others.

The Writings of Eleanor Clark, housed in boxes 1-25, is subdivided for Novels, Non-Fiction, and Shorter Works, and arranged alphabetically by title within each subdivision. The writings feature notes, drafts, proofs, and printed materials relating to Clark's published works of fiction and non-fiction. There are, for example, drafts of what would become Baldur's Gate , dating from the mid 1930s, to drafts of her last novel, Camping Out , dating to 1986. In addition, there are drafts and printed versions of numerous published and unpublished shorter works, including short stories, essays, poems, plays, speeches, readings, and book reviews. Drafts for short stories published in the collection Dr. Heart are filed alphabetically in Shorter Works, whereas drafts for the collection, published by Pantheon Books in 1974, are filed in Novels. The titles to most shorter works are listed in quotes and printed versions are noted only when present; supplied titles are bracketed.
Correspondence files relating to several of Clark's books have been preserved in Series II. Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Writings of Others, housed in boxes 26-27, is arranged alphabetically and features drafts of poems and shorter works by John Pierrepont and Ethel P. Rice.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is organized into three subseries: General Correspondence, Third Party Correspondence, and Correspondence Relating to Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General Correspondence, housed in boxes 27-37 and arranged alphabetically by correspondent, consists chiefly of incoming letters from family, friends, writers, editors and publishers, and educational and cultural institutions. Larger correspondence files may be found for Clark's husband, Robert Penn Warren, her mother and children, Louis MacNeice, Katherine Anne Porter, and Muriel Rukeyser, among others. Other noteworthy correspondents include authors W.H. Auden, Saul Bellow, Hermann Broch, Albert Camus, John Cheever, Robert Fitzgerald, Elsa Morante, Eudora Welty, Glenway Wescott, and Thornton Wilder.

General Correspondence also includes original outgoing letters from Clark to family members. Clark's letters to family members, including large files to her mother, Eleanor Phelps Clark, and daughter, Rosanna Warren, are foldered separately from incoming letters. Carbons of outgoing correspondence to others are documented in folder notes.

Third Party Correspondence, housed in box 37 and arranged alphabetically by recipient, consists of all loose third party correspondence in the collection, and includes several letters between family members. Other third party letters probably came into Clark's possession as enclosures and, over time, were separated from the original letters.

Files of correspondence relating to published works by Clark have been preserved in the subseries Correspondence Relating to Writings. These files, housed in box 38 and arranged alphabetically by title, consist chiefly of fan mail and letters from publishers. Letters from writers and correspondents found in the General Correspondence subseries are documented in folder notes. References ("see also" notes) are provided from General Correspondence where appropriate.

accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
